text:
• Situation A. Students' Observations
  • The students at Academy studied each claim in the Initial Challenge. They made some observations. Is each observation correct? Explain.

Andres's Observation

Claim 1 and Claim 4 are both ratios, and they say the same thing.

Markus's Observation

Claim 3 is a ratio, and it is the same as Claim 1 and Claim 4.

The two ratios in Claims 1 and 4 are equivalent. Claim 1 represents the ratio of students who prefer pepperoni to students who prefer cheese as a 10 cheese to 5 pepperoni. Claim 4 represents the ratio of students who prefer pepperoni to students who prefer cheese as 2 cheese to 1 pepperoni. Each quantity in the ratio of 2 to 1 can be scaled up to the fifth multiple of each quantity to get the ratio 10 to 5.

2 cheese to 1 pepperoni

↓ × 5 ↓ × 5

10 cheese to 5 pepperoni

Gia's Observation

Claims 4 and 5 are the same. I used a diagram to show why.

Diane's Observation

In Claim 7, the comparison is between the total number of students and the number of students who prefer pepperoni.

In Claims 1, 3, 4, and 5, the comparison is between students who prefer pepperoni and those who prefer cheese.

I can rewrite Claim 7 so it is about comparing students who prefer pepperoni to those who prefer cheese.

Situation B. Parents' Question

The parents think they can use ratios to figure out how many pepperoni and cheese pizzas to order. If there are 300 students, is it possible to use ratios to fins how many of each kind to order? Explain
